title: 113_s42
content: The Act titled "Criminal Antitrust Anti-Retaliation Act of 2013" amends the Antitrust Criminal Penalty Enhancement and Reform Act of 2004 to include anti-retaliation protection for whistleblowers. The Criminal Antitrust Anti-Retaliation Act of 2013 provides whistleblower protections for individuals who report violations of antitrust laws or other criminal activities to their employer or the Federal Government. Employers are prohibited from retaliating against these individuals in any way. The Criminal Antitrust Anti-Retaliation Act of 2013 protects whistleblowers who report antitrust law violations or other crimes to their employer or the government. Employers cannot retaliate against individuals who report such violations or assist in related investigations. The Criminal Antitrust Anti-Retaliation Act of 2013 protects whistleblowers reporting violations, allowing them to file complaints with the Secretary of Labor. If the Secretary does not issue a decision within 180 days, the whistleblower can bring a de novo review action in district court. The complaint procedure follows rules from section 42121(b) of title 49, United States Code. The complaint procedure under the Criminal Antitrust Anti-Retaliation Act of 2013 allows whistleblowers to file complaints with the Secretary of Labor, who must issue a decision within 180 days. If not, the whistleblower can seek review in district court. Complaints must be filed within 180 days of the violation, and failure to comply with the Secretary's orders can result in civil actions. The Secretary of Labor or the person on whose behalf the order was issued may bring a civil action in the district court of the United States for the violation. A covered individual prevailing in the action shall be entitled to reinstatement, back pay with interest, and compensation for special damages. The curr_chunk states that whistleblowers are entitled to compensation for special damages, including litigation costs and attorney's fees. It also clarifies that whistleblowers retain their rights under Federal or State law. The Senate passed S. 42 on November 4, 2013, providing anti-retaliation protections for antitrust whistleblowers.
